Award.AwardTitle: CSBR: Natural History Collections: Equipment for The Field Museum's Fossil Mammal Collection Range for the Accommodation of Nonmammalian Synapsids and the Turnbull Collection
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Field Museum of Natural History's fossil mammal collection is an invaluable resource for paleontological, paleoecological, and evolutionary research. Two components of this collection require urgent attention. Several thousand specimens collected by W. D. Turnbull during his nearly 70 year career have never been accessioned; many of the specimens, which can elucidate the early histories of modern mammal groups against the backdrop of a rapidly warming climate, have never been unpacked. The non-mammalian synapsid collection was built by iconic paleontologists and continues to provide key information about the earliest ancestors of mammals. Yet this collection is stored in overcrowded facilities with no room for anticipated expansion.

Specimens from these collections will be packaged in archival storage materials and housed in new cabinets and shelving that take advantage of existing infrastructure in the fossil mammal collection space (funded by a previous grant). Uncataloged specimens will be accessioned and cataloged. Collections data for all Field Museum fossil vertebrates will be made available online. These steps will increase the utility and accessibility of the specimens to the research community, while guaranteeing their long-term preservation for future generations. A postdoctoral researcher and two undergraduates will be trained in collections management and curation during the grant; a third undergraduate will produce podcasts describing the work and its rationale.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching purpose of this project was to integrate two lots of fossil specimens into the existing fossil mammals collection at the Field Museum of Natural History (FMNH). The first, and larger, of these lots is a series of~50 million-year old fossil mammal specimens from Wyoming. These specimens had never been unpacked or accessioned into the collection, making them essentially useless to the scientific community, despite the fact that they document a key episode of rapid global warming that occurred during the Eocene Epoch of Earth History. The second, smaller lot of specimens consist of fossils of ancient mammal relatives that lived between about 305 and 200 million years ago. They were previously housed in inadequate conditions with non-archival padding and no room for anticipated collections growth. These specimens were moved to new storage in the FMNH fossil mammal collections range that includes adequate space for growth.

 

Funding from this grant allowed the installation of 102 new specimen cabinets in the FMNH fossil mammal collection range. New shelving for oversized specimens also was purchased, as were 713 specimen drawers. These infrastructure improvements represent significant upgrades to the FMNH fossil mammal collection.

 

In total about 1000 specimens of ancient mammal relatives were processed during the course of this grant, as were approximately 2500 Eocene mammal specimens. Records in the FMNH fossil vertebrates collection database were updated for an additional ~2600 specimens. Detailed photographs were taken of the holotype specimens in the collection (holotypes are specimens on which new species names are based), and information in the FMNH fossil vertebrates collections database was processed for posting online. Map data and field notes associated with the collections also were digitized.

 

The project had several broader impacts. First, we were able to hire a postdoctoral researcher and collections assistant to take the lead on the day-to-day work on the project. They received extensive training in best practices for the care and upkeep of fossil collections, and also had a number of opportunities to serve as mentors for student interns and volunteers. Three high school interns, 13 undergraduate interns, and two other volunteers helped with the project. They received training in collections management and gained valuable first-hand experience working with fossil vertebrate collections.
